answers.answer: Infection should be ruled out first.  This can be done with a urinalysis as well as tests for STDs.You can consider evaluating for various metabolic diseases - such as diabetes and thyroid disorders with various blood tests.If the cause remains non-revealing, a referral to a urologist may be necessary for more specialized testing.  This can include urodynamic studies to look at the bladder function, as well as a potassium sensitivity test looking for interstitial cystitis.I cannot connect the vaginal liquid with your symptoms without evaluation.These options can be discussed with your personal physician or urologist.Followup with your personal physician is essential.This answer is not intended as and does not substitute for medical advice - the information presented is for patient education only. Please see your personal physician for further evaluation of your individual case.Kevin, M.D.kevinmd_b

You should see a physician.  Your problem could be as simple as a UTI or it could be something else.  The urinine is not always cloudy especially in the early stages.  Your doctor will collect a sample and determine if you have an infection.  Bacterial vaginosis is also an option which poses the risk of PID and possible infertility.  I would make an appointment with your local health clinic or your physician.
